importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruling allowing the Trump administration to deploy National Guard troops in Portland.
Deadline for attorneys on both sides to make their case for or against an en banc review of the Portland deployment ruling.
First reported appearance of federal troops in Memphis, including patrols at the Pyramid landmark.
Date when President Trump declared he was sending 200 Oregon National Guard troops to Portland over protests at an ICE facility.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The active legal and political debate over National Guard deployments in multiple cities, culminating in the en banc review deadline.
Period during which protests began in Portland and escalated, leading to federal troop deployments and legal challenges.

keyTakeAways: The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in favor of the Trump administration, allowing deployment of National Guard troops in Portland, overturning one of two lower court blocks, though the second order remains in effect.

Two Trump-appointed judges (Ryan D. Nelson and Bridget S. Bade) sided with the administration; former President Bill Clinton appointee Judge Susan P. Graber dissented, warning the ruling erodes constitutional rights, including state control over militias and First Amendment assembly rights.
The Trump administration cites violent protests at an ICE facility in Portland as justification for troop deployment, though Oregon officials and legal experts dispute the severity of the situation.
Multiple states and local officials, including Oregon, Illinois, and Tennessee, have challenged federal troop deployments, arguing they violate constitutional principles and state sovereignty.

A bipartisan group of senators, including from Oregon, requested an inquiry into the cumulative effects of domestic National Guard deployments, citing concerns over military readiness and civil rights.
The ruling sets a precedent for presidential use of the Insurrection Act and raises broader constitutional questions about executive power, state autonomy, and federal overreach.
Trump has proposed deploying National Guard troops in San Francisco and other cities, facing strong public and political opposition, including from tech leaders and local officials.

In Chicago, the state and city are seeking Supreme Court intervention to block deployment, arguing no rebellion or federal law enforcement crisis exists, and that the administration’s actions violate constitutional norms.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled in favor of the Trump administration, allowing the deployment of National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, in response to protests at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) facility. This decision overturns one of two lower court rulings blocking the deployment, though a second order remains in effect. The ruling is supported by two Trump-appointed judges, while former Clinton appointee Judge Susan P. Graber dissents, warning it undermines state sovereignty and First Amendment rights. The administration justifies the deployment as necessary to protect federal personnel and property amid violent protests, though Oregon officials argue the situation is not as severe as portrayed. The legal battle extends to other cities, including Chicago and Memphis, where similar federalization efforts have faced legal challenges and public backlash. A bipartisan group of senators has called for an inquiry into the broader implications of these deployments, citing risks to military readiness and civil rights. The case has sparked widespread protests and political debate, highlighting a significant constitutional conflict over presidential power, state autonomy, and the use of military forces in domestic unrest.
title: Appeals Court Allows Trump Administration to Deploy National Guard in Portland
